text.20: In this verse, Allah explains that a man from Pharaoh's people, who sympathized with Moses, attended the consultation held by Pharaoh with his dignitaries. In the consultation, it was decided that Moses should be killed. The man who attended the consultation came to Moses to inform him of this evil plan, because he greatly sympathized with and respected him. He asked Moses to leave Egypt immediately. Otherwise, he might be caught and killed because they were preparing a secret army to surround and capture him. He declared to Moses that everything he was saying was true and he advised Moses to flee immediately. This advice truly arose from his sincere heart for Moses' own safety.
text.21:
Hearing the advice presented by that man and seeing his attitude which displayed honesty and sincerity, Musa immediately departed in a state of constant vigilance, because behind him some of Pharaoh's soldiers were preparing to surround and capture him. How heavy was the pressure suffered by Musa. Nevertheless, he continued to try to save himself and prayed to Allah, "O my Lord, the Almighty, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, deliver me from the clutches of the oppressive people of Pharaoh." Allah answered his prayer and showed him the way to Madyan.

According to narrations, Pharaoh ordered his soldiers to chase Musa into the small roads and forbade them from using the main roads because he was sure that Musa would not take that route.
text.22:
After Moses knew that the path he was taking was the usual road people took to Madyan, he was certain that he would not get lost traversing the vast desert. Moreover, he had prayed to his Lord to always be guided to the straight path. However, even though the path he was taking was a highway commonly used by people, the distance he had to travel was very far, while he carried no provisions because he had hastily left the city of Egypt.

It is narrated that Moses walked for eight days and eight nights, without food and barefoot. There was nothing to eat except the leaves of trees. Nevertheless, his heart remained steadfast and his spirit remained strong because he had escaped Pharaoh's pursuit. He had been saved from Pharaoh's trap in his childhood, even though many male babies from the Children of Israel were killed, and now he was free from Pharaoh's pursuit in his adulthood. All of that was due to the mercy and protection of Allah. Therefore, he was certain that on that long and difficult journey, he would remain under His protection.
text.23: In this verse, it is explained that Musa eventually reached a water source in the city of Madyan. He saw there people crowded together, drawing water and giving it to their livestock. In a slightly lower place, he noticed two girls holding and restraining the ropes of their goats, which kept trying to move forward towards the people drawing water because they were very thirsty. Seeing this, Musa felt compassion in his heart, so he approached the two girls to ask why they didn't join the crowd in drawing water and giving it to their goats. They replied, "We cannot draw water until all those people have finished drawing, because we are not strong enough to compete and push our way through the crowd. Our father is very old, so he is unable to come here to draw water. That is why we are forced to wait for those people to leave, and we can only draw water if there is any leftover water that they have left behind."
text.24: Quickly, Moses drew water for the two girls so they could water their sheep. Exhausted, he sought shelter under a tree, feeling hungry and thirsty because he hadn't eaten for several days except for leaves. Moses prayed to Allah because he was in great need of His mercy and compassion, to eliminate the suffering he was experiencing.
text.25:
In this verse, it is explained how the suffering experienced by Musa ended with his prayer being answered by Allah. Unexpectedly, one of the two girls came to him somewhat shyly and said to Musa that her father was inviting Musa to come to his house merely to repay Musa's kindness in helping them draw water and give drink to their livestock. Musa could understand that the two girls came from a good family, seeing their polite demeanor when they came to him and hearing that it was not she herself who invited him to come to her house, but her father. If the girl herself had invited him, it might have created a bad impression of her.

The commentators of the Quran (mufasir) differ in opinion as to whether the girl's father was Prophet Shuaib or not. Some scholars are of the opinion that the father of the two girls was a pious religious leader who was elderly. As for the opinion that the woman's father was Prophet Shuaib, it is unacceptable because Prophet Shuaib lived long before Prophet Musa.

Finally, Musa set off with the girl to her parents' house. Upon arrival, Musa told the girl's father the story of his life with Pharaoh, how arrogant and contemptuous he was towards the Children of Israel (Bani Israil), up to the decision and order to kill him, so that he fled from Egypt for fear of being killed. The old man listened to Musa's story with great attention. After Musa finished his story, the old man said to him, "You do not need to be afraid and worried because you have escaped from the power of those unjust people. They will not be able to catch you, because you are outside the borders of their kingdom." Thus, Musa's heart felt at peace because he had found protection in the house of a religious leader who had great influence in the region.
text.26:
Apparently, the old man had no sons and no servants. Therefore, only his two daughters took care of all the family affairs, until they were forced to herd their sheep, in addition to managing the household. One of the daughters thought of asking Musa, who seemed to have a very good attitude and character and strong energy, to help as a servant in this house.

The daughter suggested to her father to hire Musa as their helper to herd sheep, fetch water, and so on because he was honest, trustworthy, and strong. The suggestion pleased her father, and he not only wanted to hire him as a helper, but he also intended to marry one of his daughters to Musa.
text.27:
The old man immediately invited Moses to talk. He frankly stated his desire to marry Moses to one of his daughters. As a dowry for this marriage, Moses had to work herding goats for eight years, and if Moses agreed to work for ten years, that would be even better. This was a very sympathetic and very relieving offer for Moses, as a fugitive wanting to avoid death, someone who was not yet sure of his future, whether he would wander aimlessly in a foreign land, because he had no definite direction to go. What could be more valuable and happier than that offer? Without hesitation, Moses had decided in his heart to accept the offer.

The scholars take evidence from this verse that a father is allowed to ask a man to become his daughter's husband. This happened a lot during the time of the Prophet Muhammad saw, and there were even women who offered themselves to be married by the Prophet Muhammad saw or for him to marry them to whomever he wanted.

Umar once offered his daughter Hafsah (who was a widow) to Abu Bakr, but Abu Bakr remained silent. Then it was offered to 'Uthman, but 'Uthman apologized because he objected. Abu Bakr told this to the Prophet. He then comforted him by saying, "May Allah give Hafsah someone better than Abu Bakr and 'Uthman." Then Hafsah was married by the Prophet Muhammad.
text.28: Moses accepted the offer and promised the father of the two girls that he would fulfill the agreed-upon conditions and would fulfill one of the two periods offered, namely eight or ten years. After that, there would be no further obligations imposed upon him. Moses also declared that Allah was a witness to the truth of what had been mutually pledged.
text.29:
This verse explains that after Moses had fulfilled his duties for ten years in the best possible way, he bid farewell to his father-in-law to return to Egypt, which was his hometown, with his wife. Of course, there was no reason for his father-in-law to hold him back because all the conditions stipulated for marrying his daughter had been met by Moses. However, as a parent, he would not have the heart to let his son-in-law and daughter go just like that, without providing some provisions for the journey. His father-in-law provided sufficient provisions and gave him several goats.

Moses then set off with his wife, taking the path he had taken before when he fled from Egypt. Along the way, he stopped at a place to rest. Because night had arrived and it was pitch dark, he tried to light a fire with stones. However, the tinder would not ignite, so he almost despaired because he could not do anything in the pitch darkness. The air was also very cold, so he and his family would not be able to endure it for long without a fire to warm themselves.

In that situation, from afar he saw a flame on the right side of Mount Tur. He then said to his wife to wait in her place because he would go to the place of the fire. Hopefully, the people there could give him directions about this journey, or he could bring back a piece of burning wood so they could warm themselves from the unbearable cold air.
text.30: Moses walked towards the fire he saw. When he was near the fire, he was called by a voice in the valley on his right. He heard a call declaring to him that it was the call of Allah, Lord of all the worlds. Moses heard the call of his Lord in the silent night, in the valley in solitude, and no one accompanied him. How could Moses hear the Divine Word directly from his Lord? Because it is a matter of the unseen (ghaib), none knows it except Allah. He inspired Moses with the conviction that the one speaking to him was the Lord of all the worlds. The valley where Moses stood was made a blessed place because it was there that Moses heard the word of his Lord and was appointed as a messenger.
text.31:
Then Allah commanded Moses to throw his staff. Moses obediently threw his staff, but the staff transformed into a large serpent that moved quickly and agilely. Moses was very surprised and felt horrified and afraid to see the serpent. Immediately, he ran without looking back. He thought of nothing but saving himself from the serpent's terrible bite.

At that time, God called out again for Moses to return to his original place and not be afraid of the serpent. The serpent was only his staff that had transformed into a serpent and would not harm him. Nothing could disturb his peace. This was a miracle that Allah gave to Moses to confront the arrogant and conceited Pharaoh. Moses' heart felt safe and peaceful after hearing that his safety was guaranteed by Allah.
text.32:
Then Allah commanded Musa to insert his hand into his garment. Musa carried out this command obediently and faithfully. When he took his hand out from the opening of his garment, he saw that his hand had turned white, radiant, and shining, not because of vitiligo or anything else. Musa was startled, surprised, and felt afraid. However, immediately after that, a command from the Lord came down to remove the shock and fear that had taken hold of him, so that he should press both his hands to his chest.

Then Allah affirmed to Musa that the two miracles given to him were to demonstrate His power. Musa was commanded to show these two miracles to the arrogant and wicked Pharaoh when Musa called him to believe in Allah and abandon the error he adhered to. At that moment, Musa understood that a message had been placed upon his shoulders that had to be conveyed to Pharaoh and his people, as well as to the Children of Israel themselves. This meant that he had become a messenger (rasul). Thus, what Allah had promised to Musa's mother, that her son would be returned to her embrace, had been fulfilled when Musa was still a child. Now, Allah's second promise was also fulfilled, that He would raise Musa to be a messenger.

Before this, what prompted Musa to leave Madyan for Egypt was a feeling of longing for his homeland and his relatives. He dared to do so because he hoped that the Egyptians had forgotten about the killing he had committed in the past, so he could enter Egypt secretly. However, he now had to return there openly and oppose the mighty power of Pharaoh. In that way, Pharaoh and his people would surely kill him. He began to feel worried about himself if he went alone. What he was more worried about was that if he was killed by Pharaoh, surely his Lord's message would not reach his people (Bani Israil).
text.33:
Moses complained to his Lord that he had once killed a young man. This had become widely known among the Egyptians, and Pharaoh had determined to kill him. This greatly worried Moses, lest upon his arrival there, Pharaoh and his people would have prepared to kill him. Thus, the message entrusted to him would be abandoned.

Moses also complained that he had a brother named Aaron who was more eloquent in speech than him, more skilled in debate and giving explanations. With his eloquence, Aaron would be able to defend him, if Pharaoh and his people made accusations that might incriminate him.
text.34:
Moses complained to his Lord that he had once killed a young man. This had become widely known among the Egyptians, and Pharaoh had resolved to kill him. This greatly worried Moses, fearing that upon his arrival there, Pharaoh and his people would be prepared to kill him. Thus, the message entrusted to him would be abandoned.

Moses also complained that he had a brother named Aaron who was more eloquent in speech than him, more skilled in debate and giving explanations. With his eloquence, Aaron would be able to defend him, if Pharaoh and his people made accusations that might incriminate him.
text.35:
Allah granted Musa's request and promised to appoint Harun as a messenger and his companion (wazir). Allah also reassured his heart, which was always filled with anxiety due to the heavy burden placed upon him. Allah promised that He would give Musa and his brother strength that could not be defeated by any power in the world, especially the very limited power of Pharaoh.

With a safe and peaceful heart, Musa returned to the place where he had left his wife. He told her about all the events he had experienced, namely that he had been appointed by Allah as a messenger. Hearing Musa's story, his wife's heart became calm. Musa then set out with his family towards Egypt, driven by a sacred ideal: to convey Allah's message to Pharaoh and the Children of Israel (Bani Israil). In Egypt, Harun was already preparing to bear that message and help his brother.
text.36:
Moses then came to Pharaoh and his people to call them to the religion of monotheism, providing clear evidence and strong, unambiguous explanations. Thus, they had no reason to reject the truth he presented. However, they immediately rejected what Moses said. When they were cornered and could no longer refute the truth he brought, they then accused it all of being mere magic, and that they had never heard what Moses said from their ancestors.

Such is the attitude of the disbelievers towards the messengers who call to the true religion, as mentioned in His saying:

"Likewise, there did not come to those before them any messenger except that they said, "A magician or a madman." (adz-dzariyat/51: 52).
text.37:
Pharaoh and his people's accusation that the evidence presented by Moses was merely magic was answered calmly and without deviating from the etiquette and politeness of debate, without accusing his opponents of being misguided. Moses told them that his Lord knows best who truly brings guidance from Allah and who is truly fortunate and will attain happiness in the Hereafter. Behind that, in his heart, he was fully convinced that he was right, that he was the fortunate one, and that whoever opposed the truth he brought would surely lose and regret it. This answer is similar to the answer given by the Prophet Muhammad to the polytheists who opposed him, as mentioned in Allah's word:

Say, "Who provides for you from the heavens and the earth?" Say, "Allah. And either we or you are rightly guided or in clear error." (Saba'/34:24)

Nevertheless, Moses still affirmed that the wrongdoers will not attain victory. This is an indication to Pharaoh and his people that they will not win. They will surely be defeated and destroyed because they are arrogant and oppressive people.
text.38:
This verse explains that after running out of reasons and arguments to refute Moses' explanations and the evidence he presented, Pharaoh ordered his people not to believe the false news that Moses was spreading. Throughout history, no one had dared to claim that there was a God other than him. Since ancient times, during the reigns of successive Pharaohs in Egypt, no one had denied that Pharaoh was the supreme god on earth. The people's minds were clouded with tales and superstitions that stated that humans must submit to Pharaoh's power. He always committed cruel and brutal acts against those who dared to deny his power as a god by torturing, imprisoning, and even killing them. This is mentioned in Allah's words:

Then he gathered (his chiefs) and proclaimed, (Saying): "I am your lord, most high." (an-Nazi'at/79: 23-24)

Allah's words:

He (Pharaoh) said, "If you take any god other than me, I will surely put you among the prisoners." (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 29)

Imam Fakhruddin ar-Razi argued that Pharaoh's claim to be God did not mean that he created the heavens, the earth, the seas, the mountains, and all of humanity, because that would not be acceptable to reason. What he meant was that people should enslave themselves to him. He only rejected the existence of a god who should be obeyed and worshipped other than him.

Then Pharaoh ordered his vizier, Haman, to light a great fire to make many bricks and build a tall structure so that he could ascend to the sky to see the God that Moses was proclaiming. Pharaoh then asserted that Moses was a great liar. In line with this, Allah says:

And Pharaoh said, "O Haman, construct for me a tower that I may reach the roads - The roads into the heavens - and look at the God of Moses. And indeed, I think he is a liar." And thus was made attractive to Pharaoh his evil deed, and he was averted from the [right] way. And the plan of Pharaoh was not except in ruin. (al-Mu'min/40: 36-37)
text.39:
In this verse, Allah affirms that Pharaoh and his army were very arrogant and haughty. Pharaoh considered and declared himself the absolute ruler on earth. Anyone who challenged him was considered wrong and disobedient. When told that there was a God greater than his power, Pharaoh became enraged and could no longer control himself, such as immediately ordering the creation of something impossible, like building a structure as high as the sky so that he could confront God Almighty and All-Powerful.

Pharaoh and his people thought that they would not be resurrected, that what they had done during their lives in the world would not be accounted for, and that no one would punish them if they committed injustice and cruelty. Indeed, that was their belief due to the influence of arrogance and haughtiness. They built large pyramids for their tombs, filled with complete and luxurious furnishings, as well as beautiful clothes and jewelry, to be enjoyed after death.

Because of their arrogance and haughtiness, Allah punished them in this world and the Hereafter. In this world, Pharaoh was drowned with his army in the sea, and in the Hereafter, they will be punished in Hell.

Such is the fate that Allah has decreed for those who are arrogant and haughty, who commit injustice and oppression against Allah and their fellow human beings. Actually, the continuation of Pharaoh's story can be found in other surahs in the Al-Qur'an such as Surah al-A'raf, Yunus, Taha, and so on. However, Allah intends to emphasize here the fate of the disobedient who no longer use their reason and intellect, so that their hearts are closed to accepting the truth from wherever it comes, causing them to become arrogant and haughty. This deserves attention and serves as a lesson for all mankind.
text.40:
In this verse, Allah affirms that Pharaoh and his army were very arrogant and conceited. Pharaoh considered and declared himself the absolute ruler on earth. Anyone who challenged him was considered wrong and disobedient. If he was told that there was a God greater than his power, Pharaoh would become enraged and lose control of himself, such as immediately ordering the creation of something impossible, like building a structure as high as the sky so that he could confront God Almighty and All-Powerful.

Pharaoh and his people thought that they would not be resurrected, that what they had done during their lives in the world would not be accounted for, and that no one would punish them if they committed injustice and cruelty. Indeed, that was their belief because of the influence of arrogance and conceit. They built large pyramids for their tombs, filled with complete and luxurious furnishings, as well as beautiful clothes and jewelry, to be enjoyed after death.

Because of this arrogance and conceit, Allah punished them in this world and the Hereafter. In this world, Pharaoh was drowned with his army in the sea, and in the Hereafter, they will be punished in Hell.

Such is the fate that Allah has decreed for those who are arrogant and conceited, committing injustice and oppression against Allah and their fellow human beings. Actually, the continuation of the story of Pharaoh can be found in other surahs in the Al-Qur'an such as Surah al-A'raf, Yunus, Taha, and so on. However, Allah intends to emphasize here the fate of the disobedient who no longer use their reason and intellect, so that their hearts are sealed from accepting the truth from wherever it comes, causing them to become arrogant and conceited. This deserves attention and serves as a lesson for all mankind.
text.41:
This verse gives the epithet to Pharaoh and his rebellious people that they are leaders who lead people to hell because they have misled people and forced everyone to disbelieve in their Lord. They felt free to commit injustice as they pleased, without any sense of justice or compassion.

In reality, they have committed two errors, an error against themselves and the error of misleading others. Therefore, it is fitting that they receive a double punishment, punishment for their own misguidance and punishment for misleading others. Therefore, there will be no helpers for them in the Hereafter and no one will free them from Allah's punishment.
text.42:
This verse gives the epithet to Pharaoh and his rebellious people that they are leaders who lead people to hell because they have misled mankind and forced everyone to disbelieve in their Lord. They feel free to commit injustice as they please, without any sense of justice or compassion.

In reality, they have committed two sins: a sin against themselves and the sin of misleading others. Therefore, it is fitting that they receive a double punishment, punishment for their own misguidance and punishment for misleading others. Therefore, there will be no helpers for them in the Hereafter and no one will free them from Allah's punishment.
text.43:
This verse explains that Allah revealed the Torah to Moses as a mercy for him and his people, who had long been oppressed and persecuted under the rule of Pharaoh. In it are wisdom and laws that guide humanity towards happiness in this world and the hereafter. Here, a great and clear difference is apparent in Allah's treatment of leaders and peoples who are disobedient, arrogant, and conceited, compared to His treatment of leaders who are righteous, sincere, and obedient to Him.

To the first group, such as Pharaoh and his people, calamities and punishments were sent, so that he was drowned with his army in the sea. To the second group, such as Moses, Aaron, and their people, a Book was revealed that would be a guide for them in navigating life, both in this world and in the hereafter. Such is the *sunnatullah* (Allah's way) that has been in effect since ancient times. How many previous communities have been destroyed by Him in various ways, as happened to the people of Prophet Noah, Prophet Saleh, Prophet Hud, and others.

From Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, sourced from the Prophet Muhammad (saw), he said, "After the Torah was revealed on the earth, Allah no longer destroyed a people with punishment from the sky or the earth, except for the inhabitants of a land who were transformed into monkeys; they were the people of the Children of Israel after the death of Prophet Moses." Then the Prophet (saw) recited this verse (al-Qasas/28: 43). (Narrated by al-Hakim)
text.44:
This verse explains that Muhammad SAW was never on the western side of the Sacred Valley of Thuwa, the place where Allah revealed the tablets of the Torah to Moses. At that time, Allah entrusted him with matters of prophethood. Because he was not one of the group of 70 people who had been chosen to listen in detail to the things that Allah revealed to Moses, Muhammad SAW could not possibly explain all of that except through revelation from Allah. Muhammad SAW was able to convey unseen things that had happened long ago and that he had not witnessed or seen at all, even though he was an 'ummi (unlettered) who could not read or write, living in the midst of an 'ummi people, and knew nothing about these things. This is clear evidence that Muhammad is truly a prophet and messenger of Allah. All of this was conveyed and narrated through the mediation of revelation from Allah. Allah says:

And they say, "Why does he not bring us a sign (evidence) from his Lord?" Has there not come to them clear evidence of what is in the former scriptures? (Taha/20: 133)
text.45: This verse explains that Allah created generation after generation from the time of Prophet Musa to Prophet Muhammad over a long period, which was a time of emptiness, so their knowledge decreased, their morals declined, and they were heading towards destruction and moral decadence. At that time, the need for a messenger to be sent to guide them to the right path was truly felt. So Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was sent, and he was informed by Allah about the circumstances and affairs of the previous prophets, as well as the circumstances and affairs of Prophet Musa. Allah also explains in this verse that Muhammad did not live with the people of Madyan to ask and learn the story of Prophet Musa from the people who witnessed the story themselves. All of this was known to Prophet Muhammad through the revelation (wahyu) that was revealed to him.
text.46: This verse explains that Prophet Muhammad was not near Mount Tur when Allah called upon Prophet Musa and when the private conversation between the two took place. Muhammad knew of this event through the holy book of the Qur'an, which was revealed to him as a mercy from Allah, in which the story is unfolded. It also contains things that bring benefit and happiness to them in this world and the hereafter, so that Muhammad could give a warning to the Quraysh people who had never received a warning before. Besides this verse being a clear proof of the prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him), it is also proof of the miraculous nature of the Qur'an, because it narrates an event that occurred hundreds of years ago. Whereas the Messenger of Allah did not witness the event, let alone be present among them.
text.47:
This verse explains that one of the wisdoms behind the sending of Muhammad to them was to reject their excuses when they later receive a painful torment for their disbelief in Allah and the sins they have committed. If Muhammad had not been sent and torment befell them, they would certainly have presented excuses and arguments. They would say, "Our Lord! Why was a messenger not sent to us before Your wrath befell us, and Your torment was sent down upon us, so that we could follow Your guidance, practice the verses that are in Your Book that was revealed to that messenger, so that we could believe in Your divinity and affirm the messenger You sent?"

Therefore, long before they were angered and tormented by Allah, Muhammad was sent to them to give warnings and threats of the wrath and torment that would befall them if they remained in the religion of their ancestors, worshiping idols, and associating partners with Allah. Thus, there is no way for them to present excuses and arguments. That is the sunnatullah that applies to every people. This is affirmed in other verses in the Al-Qur'an, such as Allah's saying:

Messengers as bearers of good news and warners, so that mankind will have no argument against Allah after the messengers (had been sent). And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise. (an-Nisa'/4: 165)

And His saying:

Whoever is guided is only guided for [the benefit of] his soul. And whoever goes astray only goes astray [in violation] against it. And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. And never would We punish until We sent a messenger. (al-Isra'/17: 15)

One of the wisdoms of sending the messengers is to stem and reject the reasons they will put forward. The wisdom of the revelation of the holy book Al-Qur'an is also to reject their reasons for saying that they did not believe because the heavenly books were only revealed to two groups, namely the Jews and Christians, as Allah swt says:

(Lest you say), "The Scripture was only sent down to two groups before us (Jews and Christians), and we were of their reading unaware." (al-An'am/6: 156)
text.48:
This verse explains that when Muhammad was sent to the Quraysh, who had never been visited by a messenger equipped with the holy book of the Qur'an, they became arrogant, opposed him, and displayed their error. They said, "Why doesn't he have miracles like the Prophet Musa, who was given miracles such as his staff turning into a snake, the sea splitting with a strike of his staff, his hand becoming white, being shaded by clouds, and so on?" Allah says:

"Then perhaps you (Muhammad), would give up some of what is revealed to you, and your breast would be tight because of it, because they say, "Why has a treasure not been sent down to him, or an angel come with him?" But you are only a warner, and Allah is Disposer of all things." (Hud/11: 12)

The Quraysh's statement was answered by pointing out that the disobedient and arrogant people in the time of Prophet Musa had denied the miracles given to Musa before. They even accused Musa and Harun of being two magicians who helped each other. Would the disbelievers of Mecca follow what the people of Prophet Musa had done? Would they deny what Muhammad brought, and say that Musa and Muhammad were magicians? Would they also not believe in the message and miracles of both of them?

Regarding the accusation that both were magicians in this verse, Sa'id bin Jubair, Mujahid, and Ibn Zaid are of the opinion that "both are magicians" refers to Musa and Harun. This was a statement of the Jews at the beginning of the prophethood. Meanwhile, Ibn 'Abbas and al-Hasan al-Basri are of the opinion that "both are magicians" refers to Musa and Muhammad saw, and this was a statement of the polytheists of the Arab nation.
text.49: Allah commanded Muhammad to challenge the disbelievers of Mecca who said that Moses and Muhammad were magicians, and the Torah and the Qur'an were merely magic, to bring a book from Allah that is more guiding and brings more benefit than those two books. The Prophet affirmed to them that he was willing to abandon the Qur'an if they were truthful in their claim, and truly able to bring the book in question.
text.50:
This verse explains that if the polytheists cannot fulfill the Prophet's challenge to bring a book from Allah that guarantees happiness more than the Torah and the Qur'an, then it means that their disobedience is actually only driven by their desires and following the baseless invitations of Satan. People who only follow their desires and obey the seduction of Satan without guidance from Allah are the most misguided, even the most misguided. Therefore, Allah forbids following desires because it will lead astray from the right path. Those who stray from the path of Allah will receive a severe punishment, Allah says:

(Allah said), "O David! Indeed, We have made you a successor (ruler) on earth, so judge between people with justice and do not follow [your] desire, as it will lead you astray from the way of Allah. Indeed, those who stray from the way of Allah will have a severe punishment because they forgot the Day of Account." (shad/38: 26)

At the end of verse 50, it is emphasized that Allah will not guide those who are zalim (oppressors) and always abandon Allah's commands, violate His prohibitions, deny His messengers, follow the will of their desires, and prioritize obedience to Satan over obedience to Allah. Those who are zalim will receive a very painful punishment in the Hereafter. Allah says:

So they (the worshipped) have denied what you say, and you are unable to avert (punishment) or help (yourselves). And whoever among you does wrong - We will make him taste a great punishment. (al-Furqan/25: 19)

And His saying:

But the factions differed among themselves. So woe to those who do wrong from a painful punishment (on the Day of Resurrection). (az-Zukhruf/43: 65)
text.51:
This verse explains that Allah revealed the Qur'an gradually, in parts according to His ordained wisdom, so that it would be easy to read, remember, understand, and able to strengthen the heart and reinforce faith. This is an answer to the request of the disbelievers who wanted the Qur'an to be revealed all at once. Allah says:

"And those who disbelieve say, "Why was the Qur'an not revealed to him all at once?" Thus [it is] that We may strengthen your heart thereby. And We have spaced it distinctly." (al-Furqan/25: 32)
text.52:
This verse explains that the People of the Book who believe in the Torah and the Gospel, and who encountered the era of the prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him), also believe in the Qur'an. They find in their holy books glad tidings about the Qur'an and the compatibility of the Qur'an's characteristics with the characteristics described in their books. This is also explained in another verse:

"And indeed, among the People of the Scripture are those who believe in Allah and what has been revealed to you and what has been revealed to them, [being] humbly submissive to Allah." (ali 'Imran/3: 199)

And His saying:

"Those to whom We have given the Book recite it with its true recital. They [are the ones who] believe in it." (al-Baqarah/2: 121)
text.53: This verse explains that when the Qur'an is recited to them, they acknowledge that the Qur'an is truly from Allah. In fact, they had already affirmed its truth before it was revealed because they had found the characteristics of Muhammad and the characteristics of the Qur'an in their holy scriptures. The People of the Book's belief in the Qur'an has existed since long ago because their ancestors read descriptions of the Qur'an's characteristics in their holy scriptures. This practice was passed down from generation to generation to their descendants long before the Qur'an was revealed.
text.54:
This verse explains that those who believe in the Qur'an after having believed in previous holy books will be given a double reward. A reward for their belief in their holy books, and a reward for their belief in the Qur'an. Patience and perseverance are needed to maintain their faith. The trials and tribulations they face are certainly very heavy, and they even receive unfair treatment because they follow Muhammad and embrace his religion.

There are three types of people who receive a double reward as explained in the words of the Prophet Muhammad:

"Three groups of people are given a reward, each doubled. A People of the Book who believed in his prophet, then he found the era (of Muhammad saw) so he also believed in him and followed him and confirmed him, then for him is a double reward. A slave who fulfills the rights of Allah 'Azza wa Jalla and the rights of his master, then for him is a double reward. And a person who has a female slave, then he feeds her, and gives her a good education, then he frees her and marries her, then for him is a double reward." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari).

In addition to patience and perseverance, they also have several qualities that bring them closer to Allah, including:

1. They repel evil with good. What they hear that is hurtful, in the form of insults and so on, is not retaliated against but is met with calmness and even forgiven.

2. They spend the sustenance that Allah has given them in the right way. They also obtain sustenance in a halal and good way. They give zakat, household expenses, donate to the construction of mosques, madrasas, recitations, the development and maintenance of orphans, and so on. In His word:

And spend in the way of Allah. (al-Baqarah/2: 195)

And His word:

O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned. (al-Baqarah/2: 267)
text.55:
This verse explains the third characteristic of those who draw near to Allah: when they hear useless speech, whether concerning worldly or religious matters, such as insults, mockery, and so on, they turn away and do not engage with it. If they are treated harshly or hurt by words or deeds, they do not retaliate in a similar manner. Instead, they face it calmly and say, "For us are our deeds, you will not be rewarded nor compensated for them. And for you are your deeds, we will not demand anything from that action, nor will we try to retaliate. Peace be upon you, we do not want to do as you do." Allah says:

And [they are] those who do not testify to falsehood, and when they pass near ill speech, they pass by with dignity. (al-Furqan/25: 72)

It is narrated by Muhammad bin Ishaq that more than twenty people from the Christians of Abyssinia visited the Messenger of Allah in Mecca after hearing news about him. They met the Prophet in the mosque and sat together. Around the Ka'bah at that time, the leaders of the Quraysh were sitting gathered. The Messenger of Allah then called the Christians of Abyssinia to believe in Allah and recited the Qur'an to them. After they heard the verses of the Qur'an, they wept profusely and spontaneously believed in Allah, trusted him, and affirmed him. They knew that the characteristics they witnessed in the Messenger of Allah were the same as the characteristics that had been explained in their holy book.

When leaving the Prophet Muhammad, they were intercepted by Abu Jahl bin Hisham and some Quraysh people, and they said, "May Allah thwart your intentions, you were sent by your friends only to find out the personal characteristics of Muhammad and then inform them. However, in reality, you have been influenced and left your religion and affirmed what Muhammad said. We have not seen a group more foolish than you." Hearing the harsh and sharp words from Abu Jahl bin Hisham, they replied, "Farewell to you, we will not retaliate or do evil to you. For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds."
text.56:
This verse explains that Muhammad cannot make his people obedient and embrace the religion he brought, even if he tries his best. He is only obligated to convey the message, and only Allah will give guidance to whomever He wills. He possesses profound wisdom and sufficient reasons. This is also affirmed in other verses in the Qur'an.

"Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [to effect] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills." (al-Baqarah/2: 272)

And His saying:

"And most of the people - although you strive [for it] - are not believers." (Yusuf/12:103)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He knows best who are willing and worthy to receive guidance. Among them are the People of the Book whose stories were narrated in the previous verses. Conversely, those who are unwilling to receive guidance, such as some of the Prophet's relatives, will not be given guidance.
text.57:
It is narrated by Ibn Jarir from Ibn 'Abbas that this verse was revealed concerning al-Haris bin Uthman bin 'Abd Manaf when he and several other Quraysh people came to the Prophet saw and they said to the Prophet, "We have come to know that what you say is true. However, what prevents us from following your religion is the Arabs who will be hostile to us and expel us from our land, and we have no ability whatsoever to fight them."

This verse explains that some of the polytheists of Mecca put forward reasons that cannot be accepted by a sound mind. They said, "If we follow the guidance given to us by Muhammad, and the religion revealed to him, we fear that we will be expelled from our land. The polytheists and figures of the Arab nations will also be hostile to us with violence, while we are unable to fight them." With this warning, it appears that they are more afraid of creatures than the God who created them. They never imagined the torment that would be inflicted upon them.

They forgot that they were in the Haram area which has been highly respected since ancient times, safe and receiving various kinds of sustenance and fruits. Did they think they would remain safe and prosperous in that safe Haram area if they remained in disbelief and polytheism? Not a few of them did not know and realize the blessings and torment of Allah that would be given to each person according to their good and bad deeds.

They should have known that the abundant sustenance comes from Allah. Therefore, He is the one who should be feared and obeyed, not humans, creatures who are weak and have many shortcomings.
text.58:
Many inhabitants of lands who initially lived comfortably with abundant wealth, but because they constantly caused corruption and did not give thanks for Allah's blessings, Allah destroyed their lands and only a few of their houses remained. Yet Allah would not destroy a land as long as its inhabitants did good deeds, as Allah says:

"And your Lord would never destroy the towns unjustly while their people were reformers." (Hud/11: 117)

After that people were destroyed, their dwellings became barren and no longer prosperous, until the land returned to its rightful owner, which is Allah. Allah says:

"And Allah presents an example: a city which was safe and secure, its provision coming to it in abundance from every place, but it denied the favors of Allah. So Allah made it taste the garment of hunger and fear for what they had been doing." (an-Nahl/16: 112)
text.59:
This verse explains that, in accordance with His sunnah, Allah never destroys a city unless He first sends a messenger to that city to recite to its inhabitants Allah's verses containing the truth. The messenger is tasked with calling and warning them to believe in Allah, but they do not heed it. Allah says:

"And We would never punish until We sent a messenger." (al-Isra'/17: 15)

After Allah sends a messenger to guide the inhabitants of the city to the straight path, giving guidance to the truth, but they continue to commit injustice and deny the messenger, rejecting His verses, then He will destroy that city and its inhabitants.

The mass destruction of a people, as happened to previous nations, will not happen to the ummah of Prophet Muhammad. He is the last prophet sent to all the worlds, so total destruction will no longer occur. What exists is only partial or local destruction such as disease outbreaks, natural disasters, earthquakes, tsunamis, and so on.

The sending of Muhammad saw as the last prophet means that Allah will not send a prophet or messenger after him. Meanwhile, the tasks of da'wah and the responsibility of giving warnings to the ummah lie on the shoulders of the ulama.
text.60:
This verse explains that what Allah gives to humans, whether in the form of wealth or offspring, is merely worldly enjoyment. The life of this world with all its adornments does not necessarily guarantee their safety and happiness. On the contrary, the reward that is with Allah, given to His obedient servants, is better, because it is eternal and everlasting. This is different from worldly pleasures that are worshipped because their time is very limited, and after that they are exhausted and perish. Allah says:

And what is with Allah is best for the righteous. (ali 'Imran/3: 198)

What you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting. (an-Nahl/16: 96)

And this worldly life is only amusement and play; and indeed, the home of the Hereafter - that is the [eternal] life, if they only knew. (al-'Ankabut/29:64)

But you prefer the worldly life, While the Hereafter is better and more enduring. (al-A'la/87: 16-17)

This verse is closed with a question that is both mocking and a warning from Allah. Why do they not want to use their minds and think deeply so that they know what is good and what is not? Do they think that the life of this world with all its fleeting pleasures that can be enjoyed in a very short time is better than the life of the Hereafter which is eternal and everlasting?
text.61:
This verse begins with a question to reassure the disbelievers, urging them to consciously think and compare which is better. Is it those who are promised by Allah that if they obey and follow His commands and avoid His prohibitions, they will be granted blessings in the Hereafter that have never been seen by eyes, heard by ears, nor have ever crossed the heart of a person, and they will truly obtain them in the Hereafter?

Which is better, those who obediently carry out Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions, or those who choose worldly pleasures but do not obey Allah's commands and commit His prohibitions? According to sound reason, of course, the first group is better than the second. This verse shows that disbelievers are given worldly pleasures, but in the Hereafter, they will be cast into Hell. Allah says:

Indeed, Hell is the worst of dwelling places and residence. (al-Furqan/25: 66)

While the believers who are patient and steadfast in facing various worldly trials, because they are certain of Allah's promise, will be admitted to Paradise in the Hereafter. Allah says:

The inhabitants of Paradise on that Day will be best in abode and best in place of rest. (al-Furqan/25: 24)

The description of Paradise promised to those who fear Allah is [that beneath it are] rivers flowing; its fruit is lasting, and so is its shade. (ar-Ra'd/13: 35)
text.62:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to warn his people about the Day when Allah will call those who mislead and hinder people from the path of Allah. Allah will say to them, "Where are My partners? Where are the angels, jinn, and idols that you considered My partners in the world? Can they release you from the torment that befalls you?" Of course not. This is stated merely as a humiliation to them. In line with this verse, Allah says:

"And you have certainly come to Us alone as We created you the first time, and you have left behind you all that We bestowed upon you. And We do not see with you your intercessors which you claimed that they were [Our] partners. Certainly [all] ties have been severed between you, and lost from you is what you used to claim." (al-An'am/6: 94)
text.63:
This verse explains the response of the misleaders and those who invite to disbelief, who try to evade responsibility for misleading others. They have been assured of wrath and have received a threat from Allah with His word:

"I will surely fill Hell with jinn and men all together." (as-Sajdah/32: 13)

Those who invite to disbelief eventually enter Hell. They say, "Our Lord, these are the ones we misled, just as we ourselves were misled. We merely invited them, and they followed our misleading invitation of their own free will. There was no compulsion whatsoever from us." When they were invited to believe in Allah, they paid no attention at all, even though the invitation was the true invitation. This kind of event is similar to the event that will occur in the Hereafter, namely the dialogue between Satan and the people he has misled, as Allah says:

And Satan will say when the matter has been concluded, "Indeed, Allah had promised you the promise of truth. And I promised you, but I betrayed you. But I had no authority over you except that I invited you, and you responded to me. So do not blame me; but blame yourselves. I cannot help you, nor can you help me. Indeed, I disbelieved in your associating me with Allah [in obedience] before." Indeed, for the wrongdoers is a painful punishment. (Ibrahim/14: 22)

Satan's defense, saying that the misguided people obeyed his invitation of their own free will, not under pressure from him because he has no power over humans, is reinforced by Allah's word to Iblis:

Indeed, you (Iblis) will have no authority over My [true] servants, except for those who follow you of the deviators. (al-Hijr/15: 42)

The misleading leaders declare that they are not responsible to Allah for the actions of their followers, on the grounds that they did not worship Him but idols. An event like this is mentioned in another verse, namely Allah's word:

[That will be] when those who were followed disassociate themselves from those who followed [them], and they [all] see the punishment, and all ties between them are severed. (al-Baqarah/2: 166)
text.64:
This verse explains that those who associate partners with Allah by worshipping other gods and objects of worship in the world are commanded to call upon their gods, which they made partners with Allah, to ward off the torment that befalls them. When they call upon them, these idols will certainly not be able to answer because they have no power whatsoever. This is done only to show their foolishness, witnessed by all the inhabitants of the Hereafter. Those who call and those who are called upon are certain that they will be dragged into Hell because of their sins, and they can no longer avoid it or flee to another place, as Allah says:

"And the criminals will see the Fire and will be certain that they are to fall therein. And they will not find from it a way to escape." (al-Kahf/18: 53)

After witnessing the torment that will befall them, they will then regret that if only they had accepted guidance and believed in Allah when they were still alive in the world. However, this supposition is only a wishful thought that cannot be realized.
text.65:
After it was declared to them that their act of associating partners with Allah was misguided, as a rebuke for their actions, this verse asks them about how they responded to the call of the messengers to purify themselves from idol worship and invite them to the creed of Tawhid, to believe in the Oneness of Allah. They were silent, unable to offer even the slightest reason as an answer to the statement made. They were confused, not knowing what to say. Therefore, they asked each other, like people facing difficulties. They were bowed down in shame and regret. If the messengers cannot answer the questions posed to them about the answers and responses of their people regarding their call to them, then surely those who are misguided and misleading in the world who do not heed the call of the prophets are even more anxious. Allah says:

"(Remember) the Day when Allah will assemble the messengers and say, "What was the response you received?" They will say, "We have no knowledge. Indeed, it is You who is the Knower of all that is unseen." (al-Ma'idah/5: 109)
text.66:
After it was declared to them that their act of associating partners with Allah was misguided, as a rebuke for their actions, this verse asks them about how they responded to the call of the messengers to purify themselves from idol worship and invite them to the creed of Tawhid, to single out Allah. They were completely silent, unable to offer even the slightest reason as an answer to the statement made. They were confused, not knowing what to say. Therefore, they asked each other, like people facing difficulty. They were bowed down in shame and regret. If the messengers cannot answer the questions posed to them about the answers and responses of their people regarding their call to them, then those who are misguided and misleading in the world who do not heed the call of the prophets will be even more anxious. Allah says:

"(Remember) the Day when Allah will assemble the messengers and say, "What was the response you received?" They will say, "We have no knowledge. Indeed, You - only You - are the Knower of all that is unseen." (al-Ma'idah/5: 109)
text.67:
No matter how numerous a person's sins, including associating partners with Allah, which is the greatest sin, if he repents and returns to the truth, and worships Him, affirms His Prophet, performs His commands, and abandons His prohibitions, then surely he is among the fortunate and happy in the Hereafter. His evil deeds are replaced by Allah with good deeds. He receives grace and enters Paradise full of blessings. He dwells therein eternally forever, as Allah says:

"And those who do not invoke with Allah another deity or kill the soul which Allah has forbidden [to be killed], except by right, and do not commit unlawful sexual intercourse. And whoever should do that will meet a penalty. Multiplied for him is the punishment on the Day of Resurrection, and he will abide therein humiliated - Except for those who repent, believe and do righteous work. For them Allah will replace their evil deeds with good. And ever is Allah Forgiving and Merciful." (al-Furqan/25: 68-70)
text.68:
This verse explains that Allah creates what He wills. He is the only One authorized to choose and determine something, both visible and invisible, as His word states:

"Does He who created not know, while He is the Subtle, the Acquainted?" (al-Mulk/67: 14)

And His word:

"Do they not know that Allah knows what they conceal and what they declare?" (al-Baqarah/2: 77)

Allah is All-Knowing of all His creatures, knowing their circumstances, nature, and character. Then He chooses from His servants, who among them are worthy and deserving of receiving guidance and being appointed as a messenger capable of carrying out his duties. Allah's word:

"Allah is most knowing of where He places His message." (al-An'am/6: 124)

When Allah has determined something, then humans cannot choose according to their desires. They must accept and obey what Allah has decreed. Allah's word:

"It is not for a believing man or a believing woman, when Allah and His Messenger have decided a matter, that they should [thereafter] have any choice about their affair." (al-Ahzab/33: 36)

This verse concludes with an explanation that Allah is Exalted and High above what they associate with Him. No one can hinder His choice and nullify His decree. No matter how much the Prophet Muhammad wanted to guide his uncle, Abu Talib, to Islam, and no matter how much the people of Mecca desired that a messenger be sent from among them, all of that failed and did not come to pass. Only Allah's choice and decree prevail and become reality.
text.69:
This verse explains that whatever is hidden in the heart and whatever a person declares, Allah certainly knows it. His word:

"It is the same (to Allah) whether any of you conceal his speech or declares it openly, and whether one hides in the night or walks about in the day." (ar-Ra'd/13: 10)

And His word:

"(He is the Lord) Knower of the unseen and the witnessed. Exalted is He above what they associate with Him." (al-Mu'minun/23: 92)

(70) In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One and Only, there is none worthy of worship except Allah. He is the Knower of all things and He is the One who has power over them. He is the One who deserves praise for all His actions, because He is the One who gives all the blessings that we obtain both in this world and in the Hereafter. All the rules and regulations that He has outlined must be valid and implemented. It is impossible to challenge because He is above all His creatures, the Most Just Judge, who determines and establishes that what is right is right and what is wrong is wrong. To Him all things will be returned, the word of Allah:

"And to Allah belong all matters." (al-Anfal/8: 44)

On the Day of Judgment, each person will be rewarded in proportion to his deeds in the world. If good, rewarded with paradise, and if evil, rewarded with torment in hell.
text.70: In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One and Only, there is none worthy of worship except Allah. He is the Knower of all things and He is the One who has power over them. He is the One who deserves to be praised for all His actions, because He is the One who gives all the blessings we receive, both in this world and in the Hereafter. All the rules and regulations that He has prescribed must be valid and implemented. It is impossible to challenge them because He is above all His creation, the Most Just Judge, who determines and establishes that what is right is right and what is wrong is wrong. To Him all things will be returned, the word of Allah: "To Allah belong all matters." (al-Anfal/8: 44) On the Day of Judgment, each person will be rewarded according to their deeds in the world. If good, they will be rewarded with Paradise, and if evil, they will be punished with the torment of Hell.
text.71:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to ask those who associate partners with Him. If Allah were to make the night continuous for all time until the Day of Judgment without any day intervening, would any of their deities have the power and ability to bring forth the day so that its light could be utilized? Do these polytheists not use their hearing? They are as if deaf. If they used their intellect properly, they would surely realize and be aware, and know with certainty that only Allah, the Almighty, can bring forth the night to replace the day when He wills. He brings forth the day to erase the night when He wills, and nothing can do such a thing.

Allah says:

And We have made the night and day two signs, and We erased the sign of the night and made the sign of the day visible... (al-Isra'/17: 12)
text.72:
This verse contains the opposite meaning of the previous verse. In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to ask the polytheists, if Allah were to make the day continuous forever until the Day of Judgment without night alternating with it, is there any god besides Allah who is able to bring the night? Do they not observe the signs of Allah's perfect power? It is as if they have no minds.

If they paid close attention, they would certainly conclude that there is none worthy of worship except the Lord who has given countless blessings and favors and has the power to make day and night alternate to create a balance. The day is made bright to seek sustenance with all available abilities. Then the day disappears, replaced by the night, whose atmosphere is suitable for releasing and eliminating fatigue so that energy and mind are restored to seek sustenance the next day. Allah says:

And it is He who has made the night and the day in succession for whoever desires to remember or desires gratitude. (al-Furqan/25: 62)

According to scientific studies, sunlight in physics is a radiation of energy waves produced from nuclear fusion and fission reactions that occur on the surface of the sun continuously. When this light is emitted continuously and for a long time, it will generate heat.

What would happen if the day continued until the Day of Judgment? Surely the air and atmosphere from second to second, from minute to minute, and from hour to hour would become increasingly hot. In just 100 hours, the air could reach temperatures above the boiling point of 100ÂºC. Therefore, oceans, lakes, rivers, and so on would boil and bubble. One can imagine what would happen if all the rivers, lakes, and oceans boiled? Likewise, the blood flowing in our bodies would also boil. In such a situation, no creature could live. Everything would die and be destroyed into flying dust.

Allah also made the night as a time of rest for humans. All of this is intended so that humans can imagine how great Allah's power is and also the protection He provides for the lives of every creature He created, especially humans who are endowed with perfect minds.
text.73:
The alternation of day and night, each with its respective function – the day used for striving to earn a livelihood and the night used for rest and relieving fatigue, thus restoring the energy that has been expended during the day – is a great and invaluable blessing from Allah that must be gratefully acknowledged. A blessing that is not appreciated will disappear, revoked and withdrawn by Allah. Conversely, a blessing that is appreciated by utilizing it in the best possible way in accordance with Allah's commands will continue to increase. Allah says:

"And [remember] when your Lord proclaimed, 'If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe.'" (Ibrahim/14: 7)
text.74: This verse explains that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will call the polytheists and say to them, "Where are My partners whom you used to claim were My partners in the world? Can they relieve you from this distressing situation now?" The polytheists are deliberately called at that time to acknowledge their worship of others besides Allah. This is also intended for them to know that associating partners with Allah is the primary cause of His wrath, just as His Oneness is the primary cause of His pleasure.
text.75:
Allah explains that on the Day of Judgment, He will bring forth a witness over every nation. Each messenger will be a witness over his respective nation, regarding the extent of their response and acceptance of the religion he brought from Allah. Prophet Muhammad will also be a witness over his ummah on the Day of Judgment, as Allah says:

"So how (will it be) when We bring from every nation a witness and We bring you, [O Muhammad], against these [people] as a witness?" (an-Nisa'/4: 41)

The polytheists on the Day of Judgment will be held accountable for their acts of shirk. They will also be asked for explanations and reasons to justify their actions, which of course they will not be able to provide any. At that time, they will know that they will be punished forever in hell. Allah says:

"So I have warned you of a Fire which is blazing. None will enter it except the most wretched one, Who denies and turns away." (al-Lail/92: 14-16)

At that time, they will realize and be certain that what Allah has explained through His Prophet is the truth. Everything they fabricated in the world, such as denying the messenger sent to them, associating partners with Allah, and so on, will completely disappear from them.
text.76:
This verse explains that Qarun (Korah) was among the people of Prophet Musa (Moses), and was even considered one of his uncles. Qarun also had another name, "al-Munawar" (the illuminated one) because of his handsome face. He read the Torah more than any of his companions from the Children of Israel, but he was a hypocrite like al-Samiri. He acted unjustly and arrogantly towards his fellow Children of Israel.

And if Allah were to extend the provision for His servants, they would surely transgress in the earth, but He sends [it] down in an amount which He wills. Indeed He is, of His servants, Aware and Seeing. (ash-Shura/42: 27)

The abundant wealth and vast treasures that Allah gave him, so much so that the keys could not be carried by a number of strong men due to their weight, caused him to be very proud, act unjustly, and be arrogant towards his peers, looking down on them with contempt. Ibn 'Abbas said that the keys to Qarun's treasures could be carried by forty strong men.

Even though he was warned by his people not to boast too much about his abundant wealth and accumulated riches, because Allah does not like those who boast, he did not heed them at all. He remained proud and arrogant. The warning and prohibition against being overly joyful and proud of Allah's gifts is also emphasized in another verse, as in His saying:

So that you may not grieve over what has escaped you nor rejoice over what He has given you. And Allah does not like everyone proud and boastful. (al-Hadid/57: 23)

Allah does not like everyone proud and boastful. (an-Nisa'/4: 36)
text.77:
In this verse, Allah explains four types of advice and guidance directed to Qarun by his people. Those who practice this advice and guidance will attain prosperity in this world and the hereafter.

1.  A person who is bestowed by Allah with abundant wealth, accumulated treasures, and numerous blessings, should utilize it in the path of Allah, be obedient and devoted to His commands, drawing closer to Him to obtain as much reward as possible in this world and the hereafter.

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Take advantage of five before five: your youth before your old age, your health before your sickness, your wealth before your poverty, your free time before your preoccupation, and your life before your death." (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from Ibn 'Abbas)

2.  Everyone is permitted to not completely abandon worldly pleasures, whether in the form of food, drink, clothing, and other pleasures, as long as they do not contradict the teachings that Allah has outlined. Allah, oneself, and one's family have rights over a person that must be fulfilled. The Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Work as if you will live forever, and be wary as if you will die tomorrow." (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from Ibn 'Umar)

3.  Everyone must do good as Allah has done good to them, for example, helping those in need, maintaining ties of kinship, and so on.

4.  Everyone is forbidden from causing corruption on earth, and from doing evil to fellow creatures, because Allah does not love those who cause corruption.
text.78:
This verse explains Qarun's reaction to the advice and guidance given by his people. He arrogantly said, "The wealth that Allah has given me is because of the knowledge I possess. Allah knows this. Therefore, He is pleased with me and has given me this wealth." It is not uncommon for people, when afflicted by danger, to return to God and pray wholeheartedly. All the prayers they know are recited in the hope that the danger afflicting them will disappear. If their intention is achieved, they then forget the God who removed the danger from them. In fact, they claim that it happened because of their intelligence, because of accurate calculations, and so on. Allah says:

"So when harm touches man, he calls upon Us; then when We grant him a favor from Us, he says, "I have only been given it because of [my] knowledge." Rather, it is a test, but most of them do not know." (az-Zumar/39: 49)

Such an admission is rejected by Allah with His words, "Did he not know that Allah had destroyed before him of generations those who were greater than him in power and greater in accumulation [of wealth]?" If Allah gave someone wealth and others only because of the intelligence and goodness within them, so that Allah was pleased with them, then He would not have destroyed the people of the past who were far richer, stronger, and smarter than Qarun. Those whom Allah is pleased with would certainly not be destroyed by Him. Did he not witness the fate of Pharaoh, who had a great kingdom and many followers, being destroyed by Allah in the blink of an eye?

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that when He intends to punish those who are steeped in sin, He will not ask how many sins they have committed, nor their type, because He is All-Knowing of all of that. In another verse, it is also affirmed as follows:

"So on that Day man and jinn will not be asked about their sin." (ar-Rahman/55: 39)
text.79:
This verse explains that one day, Qarun went out among his people in magnificent attire and excessive adornments, in a procession complete with guards, servants, and nannies, to show off his high status and greatness to the people. Such a thing is a very reprehensible trait, a cursed pride for those who are intelligent and have sound minds. This caused his people to be divided into two groups.

First, those who prioritize worldly life, who always think and strive with all their might to live luxuriously in this world. In their opinion, such a life is happiness. They also hoped to possess what Qarun possessed, namely piles of wealth and excessive riches, because that was considered a great fortune.

Thus, they would live happily and do as they pleased, experiencing worldly pleasures in all their variations. This kind of human desire still exists today, and even thrives in society. Everywhere we can witness that there are many people who strongly desire to possess what wealthy people, big entrepreneurs, and others have, such as large houses with luxurious furniture, luxury cars, land, and rice fields spanning tens or even hundreds of hectares. They do this even if it means using improper means, which are not in accordance with religious law and state regulations. This leads to fraud and corruption everywhere.
text.80:
This verse explains the second group, namely those who are knowledgeable and have sound minds. They consider the way of thinking of those belonging to the first group to be very wrong, even considered a great disaster and a real loss, because they prioritize the fleeting life of this world over the eternal life of the hereafter. The second group believes that the reward with Allah for those who believe in Allah and His Messenger and do good deeds is far better than accumulating wealth. What is with Allah is eternally lasting, while what humans possess will vanish and be destroyed, as His saying:

"Whatever you have will end, but what is with Allah is lasting." (an-Nahl/16: 96)

Verse 80 ends with an explanation that only those who are patient and diligently obey Allah's commands, avoid His prohibitions, can accept and practice the advice from the verse above. They also accept well what Allah has given them and spend it for the benefit of themselves and the community.
text.81: In this verse, Allah explains the consequence of Qarun's arrogance and pride. He, along with his house and all his splendor and wealth, was sunk into the earth. No one could save him from Allah's punishment, neither individually nor collectively. Qarun himself could not defend himself. There are not a few people who go astray and misunderstand the wealth given to them. They think that wealth is only for splendor and pleasure, so they do not channel its use in ways that are pleasing to Allah. Therefore, Allah inflicted His punishment upon them.
text.82:
This verse explains that those who initially aspired to have a position and honorable status like that once possessed by Qarun, immediately abandoned their aspirations after witnessing the punishment inflicted upon Qarun. They realized that abundant wealth and a luxurious worldly life do not lead them to Allah's pleasure. He gives sustenance to whom He wills, and withholds it from whom He wills. Allah elevates and humbles whom He wills. All of this is based on Allah's wisdom and the decrees He has ordained.

It is narrated from Ibn Mas'ud that Allah has given each person their own character just as He has distributed sustenance among them. Indeed, Allah gives wealth to those He favors, but He only bestows faith upon those He favors and loves.

They felt they had received a favor from Allah because their aspirations had not been achieved. Had they been achieved, they would have been swallowed up into the earth as Qarun had experienced. Their understanding became more firm that those who deny Allah's blessings, reject His Messenger, and the reward promised in the Hereafter for those who are obedient to Him are not fortunate. They will be destroyed by punishment, as Allah says:

"And there had come to them a messenger from among themselves, but they denied him; so punishment overtook them while they were wrongdoers." (an-Nahl/16: 113)
text.83:
This verse explains that happiness and all pleasures in the afterlife are prepared for those who are not arrogant, do not boast, and do not commit corruption on earth, such as oppression and so on. They are humble, knowing how to conduct themselves towards those who are older and have more knowledge. Towards those who are younger and have less knowledge, they are compassionate, not arrogant, and do not boast. People who are arrogant and boastful are disliked by Allah, will receive a very painful punishment, and will not enter Paradise in the afterlife, as Allah says:

"As for those who believe and do good, He will give them their full rewards and increase them out of His bounty. But as for those who disdain and are arrogant, He will punish them with a painful punishment, and they will not find besides Allah any protector or helper." (an-Nisa'/4: 173)

The Prophet Muhammad (saw) said:

"He will not enter Paradise who has an atom's weight of arrogance in his heart." (Narrated by Muslim and Abu Dawud from Ibn Mas'ud)

Verse 83 concludes with the explanation that a good end, in the form of Paradise, is obtained by those who are pious to Allah by practicing His commands, avoiding His prohibitions, and are not arrogant and do not boast like Pharaoh and Qarun.
text.84:
This verse explains that whoever comes in the Hereafter bringing one good deed will be rewarded with something better, and multiplied as much as possible. No one knows how much the multiplication will be except Allah, as a favor and mercy from Him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Whoever intends to do a good deed, then does not do it, Allah records it as a complete good deed with Him; if he intends to do a good deed and then does it, then Allah records (the reward) as ten to seven hundred times as much, even more than that." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Abbas)

In another hadith, the Messenger of Allah said:

"And whoever intends to do an evil deed and then does not do it, then Allah Almighty writes it down as a complete good deed with Him; and if he intends to do it and then does it, then Allah records for him only one evil deed." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Abbas)

This is in accordance with Allah's saying:

"And whoever brings an evil deed - then their faces will be overturned into the Fire, [and it will be said], "Are you recompensed except for what you used to do?" (an-Naml/27: 90)
text.85:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who obligated Muhammad to practice the contents of the Qur'an and to implement the laws and commands within it. He is also the One who will return Muhammad to the holy land of Mecca, his birthplace, in a state of victory, reclaiming it from the people who expelled him from there. Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) returned to Mecca with a great victory for the Muslims, because in this way he was able to develop Islam freely and suppress the will of the polytheists. This was a promise from Allah when Muhammad was constantly hurt and under heavy pressure from his people, that he would migrate leaving Mecca, and would return in a state of victory.

Besides returning to Mecca, some are of the opinion that Allah returned the Messenger to death or returned him to Paradise, as Allah says:

Say, "O my people, work according to your position; [for] indeed, I am working. And you are going to know who will have succession of [ultimate] home." Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed. (al-An'am/6: 135)
text.86:
This verse explains that Muhammad never expected the revelation of the Qur'an to him in order to know the news of previous peoples, and things that would happen afterwards, such as a religion containing happiness for mankind in this world and the hereafter, and also manners that elevate their status and enlighten their minds. Even so, Allah revealed all of that to Muhammad as a mercy from Him.

In this verse, Allah forbids the Prophet Muhammad and his ummah from helping the struggle of the disbelievers in any form. The ummah of Muhammad is instead required to help strengthen the struggle of the Muslims. Therefore, he should praise his Lord for the blessings bestowed upon him with the revelation of the holy Qur'an. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) does not need to help and assist the polytheists who deny the holy Qur'an, but should separate himself and turn away from them in accordance with Allah's saying:

"Then declare what you are commanded and turn away from the polytheists." (al-Hijr/15: 94)
text.87:
Allah encourages Muhammad not to heed the deceit of the disbelievers, and never to be influenced by them to the point that they succeed in hindering the delivery of the holy verses of the Qur'an after they have been revealed to him. Allah is always with him, strengthening and making His religion victorious over the disbelievers. In fact, the Prophet (saw) was commanded to call his people to the path of Allah and convey His religion to them, worshipping only Allah who has no partners. At the end of this verse, Allah emphasizes that Muhammad should never abandon his da'wah, and always convey his message to the polytheists, so that he is not like them, disobeying His commands. In another verse it is explained:

And never be of those who associate partners with Allah. (al-An'am/6: 14)
text.88:
In this verse, Allah forbids Prophet Muhammad from worshipping any deity other than Allah, because there is no God worthy of worship except Allah, as His saying:

"(He is) the Lord of the East and the West; there is no god but He. So take Him as a guardian." (al-Muzzammil/73: 9)

Allah is eternally everlasting even if all existing creatures have died and perished. Allah says:

"Everyone upon the earth will perish, And there will remain [only] the Face of your Lord, Owner of Majesty and Honor." (ar-Rahman/55: 26-27)

And the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"The truest word ever uttered by a poet was the saying of Labid: 'Verily, everything besides Allah is vain.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Allah is the One who possesses the kingdom, and does what He wills. He is the One who determines everything that will happen to all creatures. To Him will everything be returned, and they will be recompensed according to their respective deeds. If one does good deeds, is obedient, and compliant with Allah's commands, he will be admitted into Paradise. Conversely, if one commits disobedience and wallows in sin, he will be admitted into Hell. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, as narrated from Abu Hurairah:

"All my followers will enter Paradise except those who refuse." They said, "O Allah's Messenger! Who will refuse?" He said, "Whoever obeys me will enter Paradise, and whoever disobeys me has refused." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah).
